    Resources to Learn R

    resources_to_learn_r.Rmd

    R Textbooks

    • R for Data Science is an incredible introductory text regardless of discipline. Mastering the tools in the book will give you the tools to approach most analytic problems. (Note - no regression)

    • Using R for Introductory Econometrics is a companion book to Wooldridge’s introductory econometrics book. It doesn’t rely on the tidyverse, so it may be a confusing sequel to R4DS, but it is a useful reference for econometric techniques.

    • Principles of Econometrics with R by Constantin Colonescu (2016)

    • Using R for Introductory Econometrics by Florian Heiss (website, print book also available). A good way to learn a language is to walk through something you already know but with the new language. Heiss’ book follows baby Wooldridge, but in R.

    • Introduction to Econometrics with R is a great tool, especially if you’re coming from a Stata background.

    Online curriculums / courses

    • Prof. Soledad Prillaman teaching materials - includes R and Stata code for the same output

    • Data Science for Economists by Grant McDermott (University of Oregon). Course material includes lectures on R language basics (written with Stata users in mind), and regression in R overview.

    • PhD Econometrics by Ed Rubin (University of Oregon). PhD course taught in the “Mostly Harmless” tradition with full lecture and lab notes available.

    • Guide to R for SCU Economics Students by William A. Sundstrom (website) - An introduction to R with an economics focus.

    • Data integrity tests in R and Stata by Nick Eubank - includes guidance on how, when, why to use data integrity tests (e.g. after merge). Website also includes guidance on doing GIS in R.

    • Nick HK’s Introduction to Causality using R.

    For Stata Users

    • R for Stata User by Muenchen & Hilbe (book) - good for the basics, not for complex regressions or balance tables (you can also find online PDF versions of this instead of buying)

    • Stata 2 R Dictionary

    • R for Stata Users by Matthieu Gomez (website)

    • Getting Started in R~Stata by Oscar Torres-Reyna (Princeton) - slidedeck comparing Stata and R data exploration techniques

    • Another R-Stata dictionary by Torsten Heinrich - pretty extensive looking, haven’t used myself

    Packages

    • Stargazer - package for clean publication-ready Latex tables - see also Jake Russ’s stargazer cheatsheet webpage

    • Packages for Loading Data in R by Nick Huntington-Klein (website) - A list of packages for downloading / importing data from sources commonly used by economists.

    Data Visualization

    • Data Visualization: A Practical Introduction is an introduction to best practices in data visualization using ggplot2. It’s also an introduction tutorial to R!

    Other

    • RStudio cheatsheets - includes printable colored “cheatsheets” for several commonly used libraries.

    • Some good introductory machine learning resources in R by Jim Savage (website). Welcome to the future y’all.

    • The CRAN task view for econometrics is thorough. CRAN task views are an essential resource for domain-specific R.

    • The Urban Institute has its own website for reference and sharing code called R Programming at the Urban Institute. It doesn’t contain a lot of information about modeling, but it’s useful for our research assistants. We’re adding more content all of the time! We’ll probably add some modeling information in the future. Requests and pull requests welcome!

    • Geocomputation with R is a great place to start. It begins with an introduction to the most common spatial data types, covers operations in the burgeoning sf package, and even extends to modeling and cross validation in mlr. My sense is that many people favor R for the visualization and analysis of spatial data.

    • Econometrics by Simulation explains several econometrics concepts using simulations in R.

    • Finally, the R community is amazing. #rstats on twitter is a useful resource! So are local user groups!

    Project management

    • Happy Git and GitHub for the useR is a beginner introduction to using Git with R.

    • Code style guides:

      • tidyverse style guide
      • Google R style guide

    • Some advice on project workflow: What They Forgot to Teach You About R

    Causal Inference

    • EGAP multiple series of “10 Things You Need to Know About X”.

    • DAGs in R by Malcolm Barrett.

    • Scott Cunningham’s Causal Inference: The Mixtape

    RDD

    • Jose M. Fernandez intro to RDD using R.

    PSM

    • Jacob Simmering blog post on the problems of using PSM.

    Various

    Surviving Graduate Econometrics with R by Kevin Goulding
